To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the &app; application or this manual, follow the directions in the GNOME Feedback Page.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: You can use the &app; application to create, view, modify, or unpack an archive. An archive is a file that acts as a container for other files. An archive can contain many files, folders, and subfolders, usually in compressed form.
&app; provides only a graphical interface, and relies on command-line utilities such as tar, gzip, and bzip2 for archive operations.
If you have the appropriate command-line tools installed on your system, &app; supports the archive formats listed in the following table.
The most common archive format on UNIX and Linux systems is the tar archive compressed with gzip.
The most common archive format on Microsoft Windows systems is the archive created with PKZIP or WinZip.
You can use &app; to open and extract single files that are compressed with bzip, bzip2, gzip, lzop, or compress. You cannot use &app; to create or modify such files.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: This section provides information on how to start &app;, and describes the &app; user interface.

sect2.title: To Start &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose AccessoriesFile Roller.
Type file-roller, then press Return.

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed:
The &app; window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands that you need to work with archives in &app;.

The toolbar contains a subset of the commands that you can access from the menubar. &app; displays the toolbar by default. To hide the toolbar, choose ViewToolbar. To show the toolbar, choose ViewToolbar again.
The folderbar enables you to navigate among folders within an archive. &app; displays the folderbar only in folder view. See for more information.
The display area displays the contents of the archive.

The statusbar displays information about current &app; activity and contextual information about the archive contents. &app; displays the statusbar by default. To hide the statusbar, choose ViewStatusbar. To show the statusbar, choose ViewStatusbar again.

sect2.para: When you right-click in the &app; window, the application displays a popup menu. The popup menu contains the most common contextual archive commands.

sect1.title: Working With Archives
sect1.para: When you use &app; to work with an archive, all changes are saved to disk immediately. For example, if you delete a file from the archive, &app; deletes the file as soon as you click OK. This behavior is different to that of most applications, which save the changes to disk only when you quit the application or select Save in the menu.

In &app;, you can perform the same action in several ways. For example, you can open an archive in the following ways:
UI Component
Action
Window
Drag an archive into the &app; window from another application such as a file manager.
Menubar
Choose ArchiveOpen.
If you have recently opened the archive, choose ArchiveOpen Recent.
Toolbar
Click on the Open toolbar button.
Right-click popup menu
Right-click on the archive, then choose Open from the popup menu.
Shortcut keys
Press CtrlO.
This manual documents functionality from the menubar.
You can use &app; to open a single archive, or multiple archives.

sect2.title: To Open a Single Archive
sect2.para:
To open an archive, perform the following steps:
Choose ArchiveOpen to display the Open Archive dialog.
Select the archive that you want to open.
Click OK.

&app; automatically determines the archive type, and displays:
The archive name in the window titlebar
The archive contents in the display area
The total number of files in the archive, and the size of the archive when uncompressed, in the statusbar

If an archive is very large, or you have a slow system, opening the archive can take significant time. To abort the open operation, press Esc. Alternatively, choose ViewStop, or click on Stop in the toolbar.
If you try to open an archive that was created in a format that &app; does not recognize, the application displays an error message. See for a list of supported formats.
For information on how to open multiple archives, see .

sect2.title: To Open Multiple Archives
sect2.para: &app; opens the specified archive in the current window. If another archive is already open, &app; closes the first archive and then opens the second archive.

To open more than one archive at a time, perform the following steps:
Open the first archive in the current window.
Choose WindowsNew Window to open a new &app; window.
Open the second archive in the new &app; window. The first archive remains open in the first window.
Repeat steps 2 and 3 to open the required number of archives.

sect2.title: To Extract Files From an Archive
sect2.para:
To extract files and folders from the currently open archive, perform the following steps:
Select the files and folders that you want to extract.
Choose EditExtract to to display the Extract dialog.
Select the required extract options.
Click OK.
&app; also provides ways of extracting files from an archive in a file manager window, without opening a separate &app; window. See for more information.
For more information about the extract options, see .
To select all files in the archive, choose EditSelect All.
To deselect all files in the archive, choose EditDeselect All.

The Extract operation extracts a copy of the specified files and folders from the archive. The extracted files have the same permissions and modification date as the original files that were added to the archive.
The Extract operation does not change the contents of the archive. For information on how to delete files and folders from an archive, see . For information on how to delete an archive, see .

sect2.title: To Close an Archive
sect2.para: To close the current archive and the &app; window, choose Windows Close Window .
To close the current archive but not the &app; window, choose Archive Close .

sect1.title: Creating Archives
sect1.para: In addition to opening existing archives, you can also create new archives with &app;.

sect2.title: To Create an Archive
sect2.para:
To create an archive, perform the following steps:
Choose ArchiveNew, or click on New in the toolbar, to display the New Archive dialog.
Specify the path where &app; should place the new archive. Choose a path from the spin box, or double-click on an entry in the Folders pane, to navigate to that path. Alternatively, enter the path in the Selection text box.
Enter the name of the new archive, including the file extension, in the Selection text box.
Do not explicitly select the archive type from the Archive type drop-down list. &app; determines the archive type from the filename extension. For example, if you enter the filename archive.tar.bz2, &app; creates a bzip2-compressed tar archive. For more information about the archive formats that &app; supports, see .
Click OK. &app; creates an empty archive, but does not yet write the archive to disk.
Add files to the new archive as described in .
&app; writes a new archive to disk only when the archive contains at least one file. If you create a new archive and quit &app; before you add any files to the archive, &app; deletes the archive.

The New Archive dialog also contains the following buttons, which act on files and folders in the file system:
New Folder
Creates a new folder in the current directory.
Delete File
Deletes the file specified in the Selection text box.
Rename File
Renames the file specified in the Selection text box.

sect2.title: To Add Files to an Archive
sect2.para:
To add files to an archive, perform the following steps:
Decide where you want to add the files, then open that folder in the archive.
Choose EditAdd Files to display the Add Files and Folders dialog.
Select the files that you want to add, or enter the folder name in the Selection text box.
If you click on the folder name in the Folders pane, the Selection text box remains unchanged. You must enter the folder name manually. For example, to add the folder /aaa/bbb/ccc to an archive, use the Folders pane to navigate to the /aaa/bbb folder, then enter ccc in the Selection text box.
Click OK. &app; adds the files to the currently open folder in the archive.
The Add Files and Folders dialog provides several advanced options. See for more information.
You can also add files to an archive in a file manager window, without opening a separate &app; window. See for more information.

The Add operation adds a copy of the specified files or folders to the archive. &app; does not remove the original files and folders, which remain unchanged in the file system. The copies that are added to the archive have the same permissions and modification date as the original files and folders.

sect3.title: Advanced Add Options
sect3.para: You can use the following advanced options in the Add Files and Folders dialog to automatically select and add all files that satisfy certain criteria:

listitem.para: To automatically add all files that match a certain pattern, enter the pattern in the Selection field. The pattern can include standard wildcard symbols such as * to match any string, and ? to match any single symbol. You can enter several patterns separated by semicolons. &app; adds all files that match at least one of the patterns. The examples in the following table show how to use filename patterns to select files.

entry.para: All files with extension tar, including those in which the tar extension is followed by any sequence of symbols, such as filename.tar.gz
All files with extension jpg and all files with extension jpeg

note.para: UNIX filenames are case-sensitive by default. Select the Ignore case option to override the default behavior.

listitem.para: Select this option to add the specified file to the archive only if the archive does not contain the specified file, or if the archive contains an older version of the specified file. &app; uses the modification date to determine which file is the most recent. If the version of the file in the archive is the most recent, &app; does not add the specified file to the archive.
If you do not select this option, &app; adds the file to the archive and overwrites the previous archive contents.

tip.title: Tip
tip.para:
If you use &app; to create backups, the Add only if newer option is very useful. For example, the archive backup.tar.gz contains a backup of your home folder as it was a week ago. To update the archive to contain a backup of your home folder as it is now, perform the following steps:
Open the backup.tar.gz archive in &app;.
Click on Add.
Select your home folder in the Folders frame.
Select the Add only if newer option.
Click OK.
&app; automatically adds to the archive all files that you created during the last week, and updates all files that you modified during the last week. However, &app; does not remove from the archive the files that you deleted during the last week. The archive update operation is much faster than doing a full backup of your home folder.

listitem.para: Select this option to add all files that match the pattern, from the current folder and from subfolders.

note.para: The filename, not the subfolder name, must match the pattern.

listitem.para: If you do not select this option, &app; adds the matching files from the current folder only.

term.guilabel: Exclude folders that are symbolic links

listitem.para: Select this option to omit files from folders that are symbolic links. Symbolic links are pointers or shortcuts to other folders.
If you do not select this option, &app; adds the matching files from folders that are symbolic links.

Select this option to omit files from file systems other than the current file system. When you select this option, &app; does not add files from removable media such as CDs, floppies, and Zip disks. &app; also does not add files from other computers in the network, such as files from an NFS filesystem.
If you do not select this option, &app; adds the matching files from other file systems.
Select this option to omit files with names that end with a tilde ~, for example, file~.
If you do not select this option, &app; adds files with names that end with a tilde.
Select this option to omit files with names that start with a dot, for example, .file.
If you do not select this option, &app; adds files with names that start with a dot.
Select this option to omit files with names that match the pattern specified in the Exclude files text box. See Filename Patterns for more information about patterns.
Select this option to add all files with names that match the specified pattern in any combination of uppercase and lowercase letters.
For example, if you enter *.jpeg in the Selection text box and select the Ignore case option, &app; adds all files with extension jpeg, JPEG, or JpeG.
If you enter *.jpeg in the Selection text box and do not select the Ignore case option, &app; adds all files with extension jpeg, but not those with extension JPEG or JpeG.

sect1.title: Modifying Archives
sect1.para: The following operations modify the whole archive:

sect2.title: To Rename an Archive
sect2.para: To rename an archive, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Open the archive that you want to rename.
Choose ArchiveRename to display the Rename archive dialog.
Enter the new archive name, without a file extension.
Click on Rename. &app; renames the archive to the new filename, with the same file extension as the original file.

sect2.title: To Copy an Archive
sect2.para: To copy an archive, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Open the archive that you want to copy.
Choose ArchiveCopy to display the Copy archive dialog.

Specify the path where &app; should place the copied file. Choose a path from the spin box, or double-click on an entry in the Folders pane, to navigate to that path. Alternatively, enter the path in the Selection text box.
Click OK. &app; copies the archive to the specified position. If the specified path does not exist, &app; first creates the path and then copies the archive to the specified position.

sect2.para: The Copy archive dialog contains three other buttons: New Folder, Delete File, and Rename File. See for more information about these buttons.

sect2.title: To Move an Archive
sect2.para: To move an archive, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Open the archive that you want to move.
Choose ArchiveMove to display the Move archive dialog.

Specify the new path for the archive. Choose a path from the spin box, or double-click on an entry in the Folders pane, to navigate to that path. Alternatively, enter the path in the Selection text box.
Click OK. &app; moves the archive to the specified position. If the specified path does not exist, &app; first creates the path and then moves the archive to the specified position.

sect2.para: The Move archive dialog contains three other buttons: New Folder, Delete File, and Rename File. See for more information about these buttons.

sect2.title: To Delete an Archive
sect2.para: To delete an archive, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Open the archive that you want to delete.
Choose ArchiveDelete to display the Delete archive dialog.
Click on Delete. &app; deletes the archive.

sect1.title: Modifying the Contents of an Archive
sect1.para: You can modify the contents of an archive in the following ways:

sect2.title: To Encrypt Files in an Archive
sect2.para: For security, you may want to encrypt the files that you add to the archive.

If the archive format supports encryption, you can specify a password to encrypt the files that you add to the archive. Currently, only .zip archives support encryption. To display the Password dialog, choose Edit Password. Enter the password in the Password text box, then click OK. &app; uses the password to encrypt the files that you add to the current archive, and to decrypt the files that you extract from the current archive. &app; deletes the password when you close the archive.
For information on how to check whether an archive contains encrypted files, see .

note.para: The encryption provided by archive utilities is weak and insecure. If security is important, use a strong encryption tool such as GNU Privacy Guard.

sect2.title: To Delete Files From an Archive
sect2.para:
To delete files from the currently open archive, perform the following steps
Select the files and folders that you want to delete.
Choose EditDelete to display the Delete Files dialog.
Select the required delete option.
Click OK.

The Delete Files dialog provides the following delete options:
Delete all files and folders in the currently open archive.
Delete the selected files and folders only.
Delete all files in the currently open archive that match the specified pattern. See Filename Patterns for more information about patterns.
You cannot use this option to delete a folder. However, if all of the files in a folder match the specified pattern, &app; deletes the folder as well as the files.

sect1.title: Viewing Archives
sect1.para: &app; enables you to perform the following view operations:

sect2.title: To View the Properties of an Archive
sect2.para:
To view the properties of an archive, choose ArchiveProperties to display the Properties dialog. The Properties dialog displays the following information about the archive:
Name
The name of the archive.
Path
The position of the archive in the file system.
File size
The size of the archive contents when compressed. To learn the size of the archive contents when uncompressed, check the statusbar.
Number of files
The number of files in the archive.
Date and time
The date and time at which the archive was last modified.

sect2.title: To View the Contents of an Archive
sect2.para:
To view the contents of a &app; archive, use a Bonobo-enabled viewer. &app; displays the archive contents as a file list with the following columns:
Name
The name of a file or folder in the archive.
Size
The size of the file when the file is extracted from the archive. For a folder, the Size field is blank. For information on how to display the size of the compressed file, see .
Type
The type of the file. For a folder, the value in the Type field is Folder.
Date modified
The date on which the file was last modified. For a folder, the Date modified field is blank.
Location
The path to the file within the archive. For a folder, the Location field is blank.
If another program has modified the archive since &app; opened the archive, choose ViewReload to reload the archive contents from disk.
For information on how to customize the way that &app; displays the archive contents, see .
For more advanced tasks, use an application installed on your system. For more information, see .

sect2.title: To View a File in an Archive
sect2.para:
To view a file in an archive, perform the following steps:
Select the file.
Choose ArchiveView File.

&app; uses information from the File Types and Programs section of Advanced Desktop Preferences to automatically determine the appropriate viewer or application for the file type, and then launches that viewer or application. For more information about the differences between viewers and applications, see . If &app; cannot determine the appropriate viewer or application, &app; tries to use a text viewer to display the file contents.

You can also use a viewer or application specified by you, rather than the default viewer or application, to view a file. To use an external application to open a file, choose ArchiveOpen Files. Alternatively, right-click on the filename, then choose Open Files. &app; opens a dialog that lists all of the applications that can open files of the specified type. To select one of the applications, click on the application name and then click Open. Alternatively, enter the application name in the Application text box and then click Open to launch the application of your choice.

note.para: You cannot use &app; to change a file. If you use an application to open a file within a &app; archive and make any changes to the opened file, &app; does not save the changes in the archive, even if you click Save in the application. &app; creates a temporary copy of the file, and then passes the temporary copy to the file-editing application. When you close the file-editing application, &app; deletes the temporary copy of the file and all changes are lost.

To edit a file in a &app; archive and save your changes in the archive:
Extract the file to a temporary location.
Edit the temporary file created in step 1, and then save your changes.
Add the edited file back into the archive, that is, overwrite the original version of the file.

sect3.title: Viewers and Applications
sect3.para: Viewers do not launch a separate application to display the contents of a file. Instead, viewers show the contents of the file inside a file manager window. Viewers usually start much more quickly than applications, but have very limited functionality.

Viewers are not part of the &app; application. Viewers are provided by other GNOME applications and use special technology called bonobo which enables the viewers to work inside a file manager window. The number of viewers available to &app; depends on the bonobo-enabled applications installed on your system.

sect1.title: Customizing the Archive Display
sect1.para: You can customize the way that &app; displays the archive contents, as follows:

listitem.para: Switch between folder view and file view. For more information, see .
Specify the order in which to display files in the list. For more information, see .
Select the columns to show in the display area. For more information, see .
Display additional details about the contents of the archive. For more information, see .

sect1.para: &app; updates the display immediately, when you make any of the above customizations.

sect2.title: To Set the View Type
sect2.para: If the archive contains folders, you can show the archive contents in either folder view or file view.

sect3.title: Folder View
sect3.para: &app; displays the archive contents in folder view by default. To explicitly select folder view, choose ViewView as a Folder.

In folder view, &app; shows folders in the same way as a file manager shows folders. That is, &app; indicates folders in the display area with a folder icon and the folder name. To view the contents of a folder, double-click on the folder name.
The folderbar, which &app; displays only in folder view, contains the following:

listitem.para: The Current Location field shows the full pathname, within the archive, of the currently displayed folder.

To go up several levels in the folder tree, click on the Current Location spin box to display all levels in the folder tree above the currently displayed folder, then select the required folder. &app; displays the contents of the selected folder.
To go up one level in the folder tree, click on the Up button in the folderbar.

sect3.title: File View
sect3.para: To select file view, choose ViewView All Files.
In file view, &app; displays all files in the archive, including files from subfolders, in a single list.

sect2.title: To Sort the File List
sect2.para: You can sort the file list by name, size, type, modification date, or location.
To specify a sort order, choose ViewArrange Files and select the required sort order. Alternatively, click on the heading of the corresponding column.
To reverse the sort order, click on the column heading again, or choose ViewArrange FilesReversed Order.

For example, to sort the file list by modification date, click on the Date modified heading. &app; rearranges the file list to display the files by modification date, starting with the earliest. To display the latest files first, click on the Date modified heading again.
&app; always performs a secondary sort based on the file name. In the above example, &app; sorts by name any files that have the same modification date.

sect2.title: To Display Additional Details
sect2.para:
To check whether the archive contains encrypted files, choose EditTest Archive:
If the archive contains no encrypted files, or if the archive contains encrypted files and you have entered the correct password in the Password text box, &app; opens the Last Output dialog to list each file in the archive, and indicates that each file has status OK.
If the archive contains encrypted files and you have not entered the correct password in the Password text box, &app; displays an Error dialog. Click on Command Line Output to open the Last Output dialog, which lists each file in the archive. &app; indicates the unencrypted files with status OK, and indicates the encrypted files with status incorrect password.
For more information about file encryption, see .

To open the Last Output dialog without testing the archive, choose ViewLast Output:
If you tested the archive in the current &app; session, the Last Output dialog displays the results of the last test.
If you did not test the archive in the current &app; session, the Last Output dialog displays a list of all files in the archive, but does not indicate any status for the files. Instead, the Last Output dialog provides the compressed size of each file and the percentage of compression, and the date and time at which the file was last modified.

sect1.title: Using the File Manager to Work with an Archive
sect1.para: You can use the file manager to perform the following archive tasks:

sect2.title: To Add Files to an Archive by Using the File Manager
sect2.para:
You can use the file manager to add files to an archive, in the following ways:
Drag the files into a &app; window from a file manager window.
Use the file manager popup menu to add the files to the archive.
To use the file manager popup menu to add files to an archive, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Right-click on the files or folders in a file manager window.
Choose Add To Archive from the file manager popup menu to display a truncated version of the &app; Add Files and Folders dialog.
Enter the archive name in the Add to archive text box.
Alternatively, click on Browse to display the Select archive dialog. Select the archive, then click OK.

Select the Add only if newer option to add the specified file to the archive only if the archive does not contain the specified file, or if the archive contains an older version of the specified file. For more information about this option, see .

note.para: To select any of the other advanced options, you must invoke &app; as described in .

listitem.para: Click on Add to add the selected files to the root folder of the specified archive.

sect2.title: To Extract Files From an Archive by Using the File Manager
sect2.para:
You can use the file manager to extract files from an archive, in the following ways:
Drag the files from a &app; window into a file manager window.
Use the file manager popup menu to extract the files from the archive.
To use the file manager popup menu to extract files from an archive, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Right-click on the archive in a file manager window.

Choose one of the following extract options from the file manager popup menu:
Extract Here
&app; extracts all of the archive contents into the directory where the archive is located.
Extract In A Sub-Folder
&app; extracts all of the archive contents into a subfolder in the directory where the archive is located. The name of the subfolder is the same as the name of the archive, but without the filename extension. If the subfolder already exists, &app; overwrites the contents of the subfolder with the contents of the archive. If the subfolder does not exist, &app; creates the subfolder and then extracts the archive contents.
Extract To
&app; displays the Extract dialog. For more information about the Extract dialog, see .

note.para: When you choose Extract Here or Extract In A Sub-Folder, &app; does not extract encrypted files when extracting the archive contents. To specify extract options, either choose Extract To from the file manager popup menu, or invoke &app; as described in .

sect1.title: Extract Options
sect1.para: The Extract dialog provides the following options:

listitem.para:
The Destination folder text box specifies the folder to which &app; should extract the specified files and folders. You can enter the required value in the Destination folder text box in several ways:
Click on Browse to select a folder.
Select one of the recently used folders from the drop-down list.
Double-click on one of the folders in the Bookmarks list.
Enter the folder path directly into the Destination folder text box.
You can use the Bookmarks list to record the paths to which you frequently extract files.
To add an entry to the Bookmarks list, enter the full path in the Destination folder text box, then click on Add to Bookmarks.
To delete an entry from the Bookmarks list, select the required entry in the list, then click on Remove.

The Files section provides the following extract options:
Extract all files and folders in the currently open archive.
Extract the selected files and folders only.
Extract all files and folders in the currently open archive that match the specified pattern. See Filename Patterns for more information about patterns.
Select this option to reconstruct the folder structure when extracting the specified files and folders.

For example, you specify /tmp in the Destination folder text box and choose to extract all files. The archive contains a subfolder called doc.
If you select the Recreate folders option, &app; extracts the contents of the subfolder to /tmp/doc.
If you do not select the Recreate folders option, &app; does not create any subfolders. Instead, &app; extracts all files from the archive, including files from subfolders, to /tmp.
Select this option to overwrite any files in the destination folder that have the same name as the specified files.
If you do not select this option, &app; does not extract the specified file if an existing file with the same name already exists in the destination folder.
This option is only effective while the Overwrite existing files option is selected.

Select the Do not extract older files option to extract the specified file only if the destination folder does not contain the specified file, or if the destination folder contains an older version of the specified file. &app; uses the modification date to determine which file is the most recent. If the version of the file in the archive is older, &app; does not extract the specified file to the destination folder.

If you do not select the Do not extract older files option while the Overwrite existing files option is selected, &app; extracts the specified file from the archive and overwrites the previous contents of the destination folder.
This option is only enabled if the archive type supports encryption. Currently, only .zip archives support encryption.

If the archive contains encrypted files, enter the required password in the Password text box to decrypt the specified files during the extraction process. The required password is the encryption password that was specified when the archive was created. For more information, see .
Alternatively, you can enter the required password in the Password dialog. To display the Password dialog, choose Edit Password.
Select this option to display the contents of the destination folder in a file manager window when the extraction of the specified files is completed.
This option is the only extraction option that is saved when you quit &app;.

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para: To configure &app;, choose EditPreferences . The Preferences dialog contains the following sections:

sect2.title: General
sect2.para:
The General section provides the following options:
Compression level
Regulates the speed of compression. As the speed of the compression increases, the size of the resulting archive increases. As the speed of the compression decreases, the size of the resulting archive decreases.
Recent archives
Specifies the number of recently accessed archives in the Open Recent menu.

sect2.title: Visible Columns
sect2.para:
The Visible columns section specifies which columns &app; displays when you view the contents of an archive:
Size
Select this option to display the Size column.
Type
Select this option to display the Type column.
Date modified
Select this option to display the Date modified column.
Path
Select this option to display the Location column.
By default, &app; displays all columns. For more information about the columns, see .
